No, I'm not experiencing any of those symptoms. Do you have any past medical history or are you taking any medications? I have a history of depression and migraines, and I take fluoxetine daily.
input: A 60-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of altered mental status for 2 hours. She and her husband were at the grocery store when she suddenly could not remember why she was there or how she got there. She has not had any head trauma. She has a history of depression and migraines. She does not smoke and drinks a glass of wine each night with dinner. She takes fluoxetine daily. She appears distressed and anxious. Her vital signs are within normal limits. She is fully alert and oriented to self and place but not to time. Every few minutes she asks how she got to the emergency department. She is able to follow commands and sustain attention. She recalls 3/3 objects immediately and recalls 0/3 objects at 5 minutes. The remainder of the neurological exam shows no abnormalities.
output: Have you experienced any recent head injuries or falls?

instruction: I have a growing bump on the side of my neck that sometimes bleeds when I rub it, but it doesn't hurt or itch. May I know your age and gender? I am a 28-year-old woman. How long have you noticed the bump on your neck? I noticed it growing over the past week. Did you have any injury or trauma to the area before the bump appeared? No, there was no injury or trauma to the area before the bump appeared. Do you have any medical conditions? No, I don't have any significant past medical history.
input: A 28-year-old healthy white woman with no significant past medical history presents with an enlarging papule on her right lateral neck. She describes a 1- to 2-mm pink papule that grew to approximately 10 mm within the past week. With minimal rubbing or trauma, the papule intermittently bleeds. It is otherwise nontender and nonpruritic. She has no history of skin cancer and is taking oral contraceptives. Physical examination shows a pink, friable papule on a stalk on the right lateral neck. There are no other similar lesions seen on examination.
output: Could you please describe the appearance of the bump?

instruction: I've been having knee pain since yesterday and it's been getting worse. Could you please tell me your age and sex? I'm a 23-year-old woman. Did you experience any injury or trauma to your knee? No, there was no specific injury, but I have been playing volleyball and doing a lot of pivoting and twisting on my knee.
input: A 23-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for knee pain. The patient states it started yesterday and has been steadily worsening. She recently joined a volleyball team to try to get into shape as she was informed that weight loss would be beneficial for her at her last physical exam. She states that she has been repetitively pivoting and twisting on her knee while playing volleyball. The patient has a past medical history of polycystic ovarian syndrome and is currently taking oral contraceptive pills. Her temperature is 98.5°F (36.9°C), blood pressure is 137/88 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 12/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam reveals an obese woman with facial hair. Physical exam is notable for tenderness that is mediated with palpation over the medial aspect of the tibia just inferior to the patella. Her BMI is 37 kg/m^2. The rest of the exam of the lower extremity is not remarkable.
output: Is there any swelling in your knee?

instruction: I've been having severe lower back pain and feeling really tired for the last 3 months. Can you please tell me your age and sex? I am a 72-year-old man. Have you experienced any unintended weight loss recently? The vignette doesn't mention any weight loss.
input:
A 72-year-old man presents to the physician with severe lower back pain and fatigue for 3 months. The pain increases with activity. He has no history of a serious illness. He takes ibuprofen for pain relief. He does not smoke. The blood pressure is 105/65 mm Hg, the pulse is 86/min, the respirations are 16/min, and the temperature is 36.7℃ (98.1℉). The conjunctivae are pale. Palpation over the 1st lumbar vertebra shows tenderness. The heart, lung, and abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. No lymphadenopathy is palpated. The results of the laboratory studies show:
Laboratory test
Hemoglobin 9 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume 90 μm3
Leukocyte count 5,500/mm3 with a normal differential
Platelet count 350,000/mm3
Serum
Calcium 11.5 mg/dL
Albumin 3.8 g/dL
Urea nitrogen 54 mg/dL
Creatinine 2.5 mg/dL
Lumbosacral computed tomography (CT) scan shows a low-density lesion in the 1st lumbar vertebra and several similar lesions in the pelvic bones.
output: Understood. Have you experienced any difficulty with urination or changes in urinary habits?

instruction: I've been experiencing a buzzing sound in both of my ears and sometimes I get mildly dizzy, but it goes away on its own. Could you please tell me your age and gender? I'm a 28-year-old woman. Do you have any medical conditions? Yes, I have type 1 diabetes mellitus. When did your symptoms first start? They started about a year ago.
input: A 28-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of intermittent buzzing in both her ears. She says she sometimes has episodes of mild dizziness which resolve spontaneously. She has a 15-year history of type 1 diabetes mellitus and episodes of low back pain. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Current medications include insulin and aspirin. She works as a trombonist for a symphony orchestra. Her vital signs are within normal limits. On otoscopic examination, the tympanic membrane appears normal. Bone conduction is greater than air conduction in both ears. Weber test shows no lateralization.
output: What medications are you currently taking?

instruction: I've been having pain in my right knee for the past two days, and just last week, my right wrist was hurting. I also have a few painless blister-like bumps on my back and one on the bottom of my right foot. My right knee is swollen and tender, and it hurts when I try to straighten my wrist and fingers. Oh, and I've been running a fever. What is your age? I'm 17 years old. Are you sexually active? Yes, I am sexually active with one male partner. Have you experienced any pain during urination or genital discharge? No, I have not experienced any pain during urination or genital discharge.
input: A 17-year-old girl comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of pain in her right knee. Last week she had right wrist pain. She has no history of recent trauma. She returned from summer camp in Connecticut 2 weeks ago. She is sexually active with one male partner and uses an oral contraceptive. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F). Examination shows several painless vesiculopustular lesions on the back and one lesion on the right sole of the foot. There is swelling of the right knee with tenderness to palpation. Passive extension of the right wrist and fingers elicits pain.
output: Are you currently taking any medications or have any medical conditions?

instruction: I have severe chest pain and uneasiness. May I know your age and gender? I am a 58-year-old man.
input: A 58-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe chest pain and uneasiness. He says that symptoms onset acutely half an hour ago while he was watching television. He describes the pain as being 8/10 in intensity, sharp in character, localized to the center of the chest and retrosternal, and radiating to the back and shoulders. The patient denies any associated change in the pain with breathing or body position. He says he has associated nausea but denies any vomiting. He denies any recent history of fever, chills, or chronic cough. His past medical history is significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes mellitus for which he takes lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, simvastatin, and metformin. He reports a 30-pack-year smoking history and has 1–2 alcoholic drinks during the weekend. Family history is significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and an ST elevation myocardial infarction in his father and paternal uncle. His blood pressure is 220/110 mm Hg in the right arm and 180/100 mm Hg in the left arm. On physical examination, the patient is diaphoretic. Cardiac exam reveals a grade 2/6 diastolic decrescendo murmur loudest over the left sternal border. Remainder of the physical examination is normal. The chest radiograph shows a widened mediastinum. The electrocardiogram (ECG) reveals non-specific ST segment and T wave changes. Intravenous morphine and beta-blockers are started.
output: Do you have any medical conditions or take any medications?

instruction: I found a lump in my left breast about 6 months ago. Could you please tell me your age and sex? I'm a 24-year-old woman. Has the lump changed in size or caused any pain? The lump has not really gotten bigger and it doesn't hurt.
input: A 24-year-old woman with a past medical history significant only for endometriosis presents to the outpatient clinic with a 2-cm left breast mass that she first identified 6 months earlier. On review of systems, the patient states that the mass is not painful and, by her estimation, has not significantly increased in size since she first noticed it. On physical examination, there is a palpable, round, rubbery, mobile mass approximately 2 cm in diameter.
output: Do you have any family history of breast cancer or other cancers?

instruction: I've been having trouble staying awake in the evening, feeling unusually tired early on, increased sleepiness during the day, feeling fatigued, and I'm having a hard time concentrating. Could you please tell me your age and sex? I am a 71-year-old woman. Are you currently on any medications or have any existing medical conditions? No, I'm not on any medications and I don't have any history of severe illness. Have you experienced any memory problems or difficulty with cognitive tasks? I've been having difficulty concentrating. Have you been experiencing any feelings of sadness or depression? I haven't mentioned any feelings of sadness or depression.
input: A 71-year-old woman comes to her doctor because she is having trouble staying awake in the evening. Over the past year, she has noticed that she gets tired unusually early in the evenings and has trouble staying awake through dinner. She also experiences increased daytime sleepiness, fatigue, and difficulty concentrating. She typically goes to bed around 9 PM and gets out of bed between 2 and 3 AM. She does not have any trouble falling asleep. She takes 30-minute to 1-hour daytime naps approximately 3 times per week. She has no history of severe illness and does not take any medication.
output: Have you noticed any changes in your sleep patterns, such as difficulty falling asleep or staying asleep?

instruction: I have this slowly growing spot on my upper back that sometimes gets irritated and itchy, especially when it rubs against my bra.
input: A 68-year-old female presents to dermatology for a slowly enlargening lesion on the left uppper back. She denies any personal or family history of skin cancer. She lesion has been present for several years and slowly enlargening. Sometimes it gets irritated and itchy against her bra. She denies any pain or spontaneous bleeding. On examination of the left upper back is a flat topped stuck on appearing thin browh hyperkeratotic papule with milial-like cysts on dermoscopy.
output: May I know your age and gender?

instruction: I've noticed some changes in my vision clarity. How old are you? I am 59 years old. What is your gender? I am a man. Do you have any pre-existing medical conditions? Yes, I have high blood pressure, type II diabetes, and ankylosing spondylitis. Can you describe your vision changes in more detail? My eyesight isn't as sharp as it used to be.
input: A 59-year-old man presents to his ophthalmologist for an annual eye exam. The patient reports feeling well and has noticed some changes in his visual acuity. Medical history is significant for hypertension, type II diabetes, and ankylosing spondylitis. He is currently taking lisinopril, metformin, and naproxen. Family history is significant for glaucoma in his mother and father. His intraocular pressure is 17 mmHg in the left eye and 18 mmHg in the right eye. The patient undergoes a slit-lamp examination and the findings are shown in Figure A.
output: Have you noticed any floaters or flashes of light in your vision?

instruction: I've been noticing some light spots on my legs that seem to be getting more frequent.
input: A 50-year-old African American male with past medical history of hypertension and hypertension presents for evaluation of light spots on his legs that he initially noticed one year ago. The lesions are not painful or itchy, but he is concerned that they are increasing in frequency. When they first develop they do not significantly grow in size. He has not tried any treatments. Physical examination demonstrates multiple hypopigmented ovoid macules scattered on the distal shins bilaterally.
output: Could you please tell me your age and sex?

instruction: My left eye isn't seeing as well as it usually does and it looks red and irritated. Could you please tell me your age and sex? I'm a 47-year-old man.
input: A 47-year-old man presents to his ophthalmologist for abnormal vision. The patient was discharged from the hospital 2 weeks ago after a motor vehicle accident where he was given 1L of blood. He also underwent several surgical procedures including enucleation of the right globe and exploratory abdominal laparotomy to stop internal bleeding. Currently, he states that he has noticed decreased vision in his left eye. The patient has a past medical history of poorly controlled diabetes, asthma, and atopic dermatitis. His temperature is 98.9°F (37.2°C), blood pressure is 167/108 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Physical exam is notable for 20/200 vision in the patient's left eye, which is worse than usual. The patient's left eye appears red and irritated.
output: How long have you been experiencing these symptoms?

instruction: I've been getting increasingly confused lately, sometimes staring off into space, and I've been forgetting why I walked into rooms. Can you please tell me your age and sex? I'm a 72-year-old man. Are you currently taking any medications or have any medical conditions? Yes, I have atrial fibrillation, diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and osteoarthritis, and I take aspirin, warfarin, insulin, lisinopril, simvastatin, and ibuprofen. Have you had any recent falls or head injuries? Yes, I had a bad fall 3 weeks ago when I tripped on the sidewalk getting the mail.
input: A 72-year-old man is brought into clinic by his daughter for increasing confusion. The daughter states that over the past 2 weeks, she has noticed that the patient “seems to stare off into space.” She reports he has multiple episodes a day during which he will walk into a room and forget why. She is also worried about his balance. She endorses that he has had several falls, the worst being 3 weeks ago when he tripped on the sidewalk getting the mail. The patient denies loss of consciousness, pre-syncope, chest pain, palpitations, urinary incontinence, or bowel incontinence. He complains of headache but denies dizziness. He reports nausea and a few episodes of non-bloody emesis but denies abdominal pain, constipation, or diarrhea. The patient’s medical history is significant for atrial fibrillation, diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and osteoarthritis. He takes aspirin, warfarin, insulin, lisinopril, simvastatin, and ibuprofen. He drinks a half glass of whisky after dinner every night and smokes a cigar on the weekends. On physical examination, he is oriented to name and place but not to date. He is unable to spell "world" backward. When asked to remember 3 words, he recalls only 2. There are no motor or sensory deficits.
output: Have you experienced any headaches since your fall?

instruction: I've had a really itchy spot on my upper back that doesn't seem to go away, and sometimes I feel numbness and tingling there. Could you please tell me your age and gender? I am a 56-year-old female. How long have you had this itchy spot? I've had it for the past three years. Do you have any history of neck or back problems? I haven't had any neck or back problems.
input: A 56-year-old female presents with an intensely itchy patch on her right upper back for the past three years with intermittent sensations of numbness and tingling. She denies any trauma to the area. She only applies topical over the counter hydrocortisone without any relief. She denies any history of eczema and only takes multivitamins on a daily basis. Examination of the right scapula reveals a poorly defined hyperpigmented ruddy brown ovoid patch without significant lichenification.
output: Have you noticed any skin changes at the itchy area?

instruction: I've been having a low-grade fever, an itchy rash, and my joints have been hurting everywhere for the past two days. How old are you? I am 8 years old. Are you male or female? I am a girl.
input: An 8-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of low-grade fever, itchy rash, and generalized joint pain. The rash initially started in the antecubital and popliteal fossae and then spread to her trunk and distal extremities. One week ago, she was diagnosed with acute sinusitis and was started on amoxicillin. She has no history of adverse drug reactions and immunizations are up-to-date. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows periorbital edema and multiple erythematous, annular plaques of variable sizes over her entire body. One of the lesions in the right popliteal fossa has an area of central clearing and the patient's mother reports that it has been present for over 24 hours. Urinalysis is normal.
output: Can you describe what the rash looks like?

instruction: I'm feeling a sudden fever, headache, I'm not feeling like eating, very tired, and just generally unwell. Can you please tell me your age and sex? I'm a 22-year-old woman. Are you currently taking any medications? I haven't mentioned any medications.
input: A 22-year-old woman at 30 weeks gestation presents to the obstetrician with the sudden onset of fever, headache, anorexia, fatigue, and malaise. She mentioned that she had eaten ice cream 3 days ago. Blood cultures show gram-positive rods that are catalase-positive and display distinctive tumbling motility in liquid medium.
output: When did your symptoms start?

instruction: I've been having weakness in my legs for one day. How old are you? I am 2 years old. What is your sex? I am a girl.
input: A 2-year-old girl who emigrated from Pakistan 2 weeks ago is brought to the emergency department because of lower limb weakness for one-day. One week ago, she had a 3-day episode of flu-like symptoms that resolved without treatment. She has not yet received any routine childhood vaccinations. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ in the right lower extremity and absent in the left lower extremity. Analysis of cerebrospinal fluid shows a leukocyte count of 38 cells/mm3 (68% lymphocytes), a protein concentration of 49 mg/dL, and a glucose concentration of 60 mg/dL.
output: Have you had any recent illnesses or vaccinations?

instruction: I've been feeling feverish and really tired lately. Could you please tell me your age? I'm 33 years old. How long have you been experiencing these symptoms? I haven't felt well since I got back from my hiking trip in Alabama. Could you please tell me your sex? I am a man. Did you notice any tick or insect bites during your trip? I didn't notice any tick or insect bites. Are you experiencing any other symptoms like rash, muscle aches, or headaches? No, I haven't noticed any other symptoms like rashes, muscle aches, or headaches. Do you have any respiratory symptoms like cough or shortness of breath? No, I don't have a cough or shortness of breath. Did you come into contact with bat or bird droppings during your hiking trip? You didn't provide this information, so I cannot comment on it. Do you have any gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea? No, I don't have nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.
input:
A 33-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a fever and fatigue. He states that he has not felt well since he returned from a hiking trip in Alabama. He is generally healthy and has no other medical conditions. His temperature is 101°F (38.3°C), blood pressure is 127/85 mmHg, pulse is 108/min, respirations are 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical exam including a full dermatologic inspection is unremarkable. Laboratory studies are ordered as seen below.

Hemoglobin: 13 g/dL
Hematocrit: 39%
Leukocyte count: 2,200/mm^3 with normal differential
Platelet count: 77,000/mm^3

Serum:
Na+: 139 mEq/L
Cl-: 100 mEq/L
K+: 4.3 mEq/L
HCO3-: 24 mEq/L
BUN: 19 mg/dL
Glucose: 98 mg/dL
Creatinine: 1.3 mg/dL
Ca2+: 10.2 mg/dL
AST: 92 U/L
ALT: 100 U/L
output: Do you have any underlying medical conditions?

instruction: I can't seem to remember working at a company from a few years ago, even though someone said I worked with them there. Could you please tell me your age and gender? I am a 32-year-old woman. Are you currently taking any medications? No, I'm not taking any medications. Do you have any history of medical conditions or surgeries? No, I don't have any significant medical history or surgeries. Have you experienced any head injuries or trauma recently? No, I haven't experienced any head injuries or trauma recently.
input: A 32-year-old woman presents to a psychiatrist to discuss a recent event in her life. At a social function 2 days back, she met a man who introduced himself as having worked with her at another private company 3 years ago. However, she did not recognize him. She also says that she does not remember working at any such company at any time during her life. However, the patient’s husband says that she had indeed worked at that company for three months and had quit due to her boss’s abusive behavior towards her. The man who met her at the function had actually been her colleague at that job.  I am really not able to recall any memories of having worked at any such company. What’s going on here?”. Her husband adds that after she quit the job, her mood frequently has been low. The patient denies any crying episodes, suicidal ideas, not enjoying recreational activities or feelings of worthlessness. Her appetite and sleep patterns are normal. She is otherwise a healthy woman with no significant medical history and lives a normal social and occupational life. The patient reports no history of smoking, alcohol, or substance use. On physical examination, she is alert and well-oriented to time, place and person. During memory testing, she correctly remembers the date of her marriage that took place 5 years back and the food she ate over the last 2 days. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
output: Have you been experiencing any other symptoms like confusion or difficulty concentrating?

instruction: I've been having a headache, feeling generally unwell, and a sharp pain on the right side of my head.
input: A 42-year-old man presents with a four-day history of experiencing headache, malaise, and stabbing right-sided headache. Two days after his initial symptoms appeared, he developed a rash over the area of pain. He reports that he went hiking through the Texas hill country prior to becoming ill. The patient is otherwise in good health and has an unremarkable medical history. Physical examination reveals unilateral erythematous, thin, raised plaques over the right forehead. In addition, he has no relevant social or family history.
output: Could you please tell me your age and sex?

instruction: I've got a rash on my face that's spread to my body and I feel a bit warm.
input: A 7-year-old boy presents to an urgent care center for a rash that began approximately 2 days ago. According to his mother, it began as a pink rash on his face and has subsequently spread to his trunk. The child was adopted and has not yet begun care with his pediatrician. His temperature is 100.2°F (37.9°C), blood pressure is 104/74 mmHg, pulse is 99/min, respirations are 19/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical exam is notable for the rash in Figure A and posterior cervical lymphadenopathy. The child is otherwise interactive and is quietly playing with toys.
output: What's your age and sex?

instruction: I've been having an aggressive cough with a lot of thick, foamy, yellow-green spit.
input: A 51-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of an aggressive cough with copious amounts of thick, foamy, yellow-green sputum. She says she has had this cough for about 11 years with exacerbations similar to her presentation today. She also reports that her cough is worse in the morning. She was evaluated multiple times in the past because of recurrent bouts of bronchitis that have required treatment with antibiotics. She is a non-smoker. On physical examination, the blood pressure is 125/78 mm Hg, pulse rate is 80/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F). Chest auscultation reveals crackles and wheezing over the right middle lobe and the rest of her physical examinations are normal. The chest X-ray shows irregular opacities in the right middle lobe and diffuse airway thickening.
output: What is your age and sex?

instruction: I have tan patches on my trunk and upper arms and freckles under my arms, and the tip of my thumbnail has a reddish discoloration that's painful sometimes and sensitive to cold.
input: A healthy 16-year-old girl presents with six tan patches on her trunk and upper arms, freckles in her axillae, and a reddish discoloration under the tip of her thumbnail. The tan patches have been present since birth but have enlarged over the past 4 years. She reports paroxysmal pain and cold sensitivity involving the discolored portion of her thumb. Examination reveals six tan-brown macules with smooth borders ranging from 16 to 20 mm, axillary freckling, and a tender red-blue nodule under the thumbnail.
output: Could you please tell me your age and sex?

instruction: I've been having headaches, mostly in the morning, but they get better later in the day. Could you please tell me your age and sex? I'm a 7-year-old boy. Do you experience any nausea or vomiting with your headaches? My parent didn't mention me having nausea or vomiting. Are you experiencing any changes in your vision, such as blurred vision or double vision? My parent didn't say anything about changes in my vision. Are you experiencing any weakness or difficulty with walking or using your arms and legs? I seem uncoordinated and my walking isn't steady.
input: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for a headache. The patient’s parent states that he normally has headaches in the morning; however, they tend to dissipate as the day goes on. They state he is otherwise healthy. The patient’s vitals are unremarkable. Physical exam is notable for a healthy young child. Notably, his gait is ataxic and he seems uncoordinated. An MRI scan of the head is performed as seen in Figure A.
output: Do you have any medical history of illness or are you taking any medications?

instruction: I've been having this intermittent rash that burns, and it's been happening for about a year. How old are you? I am 54 years old. Where is the rash located on your body? The rash is on my arms, legs, back, and abdomen. What is your gender? I am a woman. Are you currently taking any medications? I tried antihistamines for the rash, but they didn't help. Do you have any other medical conditions? I have a history of depression. Can you describe the appearance of the rash? The rash looks like red, raised welts on my skin.
input: A 54-year-old woman with a history of depression presents to the clinic with a 1-year history of an intermittent rash. She was hospitalized for COVID-19 approximately 1 year ago and soon after developed a rash all over her body. The lesions persist for several days and have a burning sensation. The patient has no associated joint pain or other systemic symptoms. She tried antihistamines for the rash with no symptomatic relief. On examination, erythematous wheals are evident on her arms and legs as well as her back and abdomen.
output: Have you noticed any triggers that bring on the rash?

instruction: I've lost my appetite, haven't been wanting to eat much, and have lost 15 pounds in the last 3 months. Could you please tell me your age and gender? I'm a 16-year-old girl. Are you currently taking any medications or have any medical conditions? No, I'm not taking any medications or have any known medical conditions.
input: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the physician because her mother is concerned about her lack of appetite and poor weight gain. She has had a 7-kg (15-lb) weight loss over the past 3 months. The patient states that she should try to lose more weight because she does not want to be overweight anymore. She maintains a diary of her daily calorie intake. Menarche was at the age of 13 years, and her last menstrual period was 3 months ago. She is on the high school track team. She is sexually active with 2 male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. She is at 50th percentile for height and below the 5th percentile for weight and BMI. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 58/min and blood pressure is 96/60 mm Hg. Examination shows fine hair over the trunk and extremities.
output: Have you been feeling depressed or anxious lately?

instruction: I've been having increasing pain and swelling in my right knee for 12 days and it hurts to move it. What is your age? I am 17 years old. What is your gender? I am a boy. Do you have a fever? Yes, I have a fever of 38°C (100.4°F). Do you take any medications or have any medical conditions? No, I haven't mentioned taking any medications or having any medical conditions. Have you had any recent injuries to your knee? No, I haven't mentioned any recent injuries to my knee. Are you sexually active? Yes, I am sexually active with 2 female partners. Do you have any pain during urination or genital discharge? I've had episodes of pain with urination for 3 weeks, but no mention of genital discharge.
input:
A 17-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of increasing pain and swelling of his right knee for 12 days. He has had episodes of pain with urination for 3 weeks. He had a painful, swollen left ankle joint that resolved without treatment one week ago. His mother has rheumatoid arthritis. He is sexually active with 2 female partners and uses condoms inconsistently. He appears anxious. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 68/min, and blood pressure is 100/80 mm Hg. Examination shows bilateral inflammation of the conjunctiva. The right knee is tender, erythematous, and swollen; range of motion is limited by pain. There is tenderness at the left Achilles tendon insertion site. Genital examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 14.5 g/dL
Leukocyte count 12,300/mm3
Platelet count 310,000/mm3
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 38 mm/h
Serum
Urea nitrogen 18 mg/dL
Glucose 89 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.0 mg/dL
Urine
Protein negative
Blood negative
WBC 12–16/hpf
RBC 1–2/hpf
An ELISA test for HIV is negative. Arthrocentesis is done. The synovial fluid is cloudy and a Gram stain is negative. Analysis of the synovial fluid shows a leukocyte count of 26,000/mm3 and 75% neutrophils.
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Reactive arthritis

instruction: I've been feeling increasingly withdrawn for the last two years. How old are you? I am 17 years old. What is your gender? I am a boy. Have you experienced any changes in your mood? My affect is flattened. Have you experienced any hallucinations or delusions? No, there are no hallucinations or delusions. Have you been feeling sad or depressed? I haven't mentioned feeling sad or depressed specifically.
input: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of increasingly withdrawn behavior for the last two years. His mother reports that in the last 2–3 years of high school, her son has spent most of his time in his room playing video games. He does not have any friends and has never had a girlfriend. He usually refuses to attend family dinner and avoids contact with his siblings. The patient states that he prefers being on his own. When asked how much playing video games means to him, he replies that “it's okay.” When his mother starts crying during the visit, he appears indifferent. Physical and neurologic examinations show no other abnormalities. On mental status examination, his thought process is organized and logical. His affect is flattened.
output: Do you have difficulty forming or maintaining relationships?

instruction: I have a painless growing black spot on my left hand and arm and I've been feeling short of breath lately. How old are you? I'm 14 years old. What is your sex? I am male. How long have you had the spot? It started as a yellow pus spot that slowly got bigger and then popped with yellow fluid coming out. Have you recently been in contact with animals or animal products? Yes, I've been working with farm animals like pigs, sheep, and cattle on my parents' farm.
input: A 14-year-old male with no pertinent past medical history presents with a painless growing black spot on his left hand and arm. States he thinks it may have occured after working with farm animals including pigs, sheep, and cattle on his parents farm. Parents states it began as a yellow pus spot that slowly enlargened and popped with yellow fluid exiting. Review of symptoms remarkable for new shortness of breath and otherwise negative. Examination revealed an edematous pink-brown violaceous plaques with central necrotic escharsand surrounding erythema on the left hand and arm. Punch biopsy is performed and demonstrates gram positive spore-forming rods.
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Cutaneous anthrax

instruction: I've been having trouble staying awake in the evening, feeling unusually tired early on, increased sleepiness during the day, feeling fatigued, and I'm having a hard time concentrating. Could you please tell me your age and sex? I am a 71-year-old woman.
input: A 71-year-old woman comes to her doctor because she is having trouble staying awake in the evening. Over the past year, she has noticed that she gets tired unusually early in the evenings and has trouble staying awake through dinner. She also experiences increased daytime sleepiness, fatigue, and difficulty concentrating. She typically goes to bed around 9 PM and gets out of bed between 2 and 3 AM. She does not have any trouble falling asleep. She takes 30-minute to 1-hour daytime naps approximately 3 times per week. She has no history of severe illness and does not take any medication.
output: Are you currently on any medications or have any existing medical conditions?

instruction: I've been experiencing severe pain over my neck, back, and shoulders for the past year, and it gets worse with exercise and when I don't get enough sleep.
input: A 39-year-old woman comes to the physician because of recurrent episodes of severe pain over her neck, back, and shoulders for the past year. The pain worsens with exercise and lack of sleep. Use of over-the-counter analgesics have not resolved her symptoms. She also has stiffness of the shoulders and knees and tingling in her upper extremities that is worse in the morning. She takes escitalopram for generalized anxiety disorder. She also has tension headaches several times a month. Her maternal uncle has ankylosing spondylitis. Examination shows marked tenderness over the posterior neck, bilateral mid trapezius, and medial aspect of the left knee. Muscle strength is normal. Laboratory studies, including a complete blood count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and thyroid-stimulating hormone are within the reference ranges. X-rays of her cervical and lumbar spine show no abnormalities.
output: What is your age and sex?

instruction: I've been having mild abdominal discomfort and feeling nauseous since yesterday. May I know your age and gender? I am a 32-year-old woman. When was your last menstrual period? I am currently 35 weeks pregnant.
input:
A 32-year-old woman gravida 2, para 1, at 35 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital 1 hour after spontaneous rupture of membranes. She has had mild abdominal discomfort and nausea for a day. Her pregnancy has been complicated by gestational diabetes, which is controlled with a strict diet. Her first child was delivered by lower segment transverse cesarean section because of placental abruption. Current medications include iron and vitamin supplements. Her immunizations are up-to-date. Her temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 122/min, and blood pressure is 110/78 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows severe, diffuse tenderness throughout the lower quadrants. Speculum examination confirms rupture of membranes with drainage of malodorous, blood-tinged fluid. Ultrasonography shows the fetus in a cephalic presentation. The fetal heart rate is 175/min and reactive with no decelerations. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 11.1 g/dL
Leukocyte count 13,100/mm3
Serum
Na+ 136 mEq/L
Cl- 101 mEq/L
K+ 3.9 mEq/L
Glucose 108 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.1 mg/dL
Urine
Protein Negative
Glucose 1+
Blood Negative
WBC 3–4/hpf
RBC Negative
Nitrites Negative
output: Are you experiencing any contractions or abdominal tightening?

instruction: I have a rash and swelling of my hands and feet. Could you please tell me your age and sex? I am a 7-month-old female. Has she had any fever? Yes, I've had high fevers up to 103 degrees Fahrenheit for the past six days.
input: A 7-month-old female presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a rash and swelling of the hands and feet. Patient's mother reports the patient developed high fevers up to 103 Farenheit over the past six days, rough skin on the chest, back, arms and swelling in the hands and feet. Mother denies any recent travel or any medication exposures. Review of systems is positive for conjunctival injection. Physical examination is remarkable for palpable cervical lymph nodes, multiple prominent tongue papillae, diffuse background erythematous patches across the chest, back, and arms. Swelling of the hands and feet is appreciated.
output: Has she had any redness in her eyes?

instruction: I've been waking up early in the morning looking pale, feeling really hot and tired, and I feel like I'm going to be sick to my stomach. Then I throw up a lot over the day. How old are you? I am 5 years old. Are you a boy or a girl? I am a boy. Do you have any medical conditions or take any medications? No, I don't have any medical conditions and I don't take any medications. Do you have any headaches? No, I don't have headaches.
input: A 5-year-old male is brought to the pediatrician by his mother, who relates a primary complaint of a recent history of five independent episodes of vomiting over the last 10 months, most recently 3 weeks ago. Each time, he has awoken early in the morning appearing pale, feverish, lethargic, and complaining of severe nausea. This is followed by 8-12 episodes of non-bilious vomiting over the next 24 hours. Between these episodes he returns to normal activity. He has no significant past medical history and takes no other medications. Review of systems is negative for changes in vision, gait disturbance, or blood in his stool. His family history is significant only for migraine headaches. Vital signs and physical examination are within normal limits. Initial complete blood count, comprehensive metabolic panel, and abdominal radiograph were unremarkable.
output: Do you have any stomach pain?

instruction: I experienced sudden leg weakness in my left leg while walking my dog earlier today. What is your age and sex? I am a 68-year-old woman. Do you have any other symptoms? No, I had no other symptoms except for the left-leg weakness. Do you have any pre-existing medical conditions? Yes, I have a history of high blood pressure and high cholesterol. Is the leg weakness still present, or has it improved? The leg weakness resolved completely while I was on my way to the emergency department; I can move my leg normally now.
input: A 68-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for leg weakness. About 4 hours ago, she was out walking her dog when she had a sudden onset of left-leg weakness. She had no prior symptoms and noticed nothing else except that she was unable to move her left leg like she normally could. This weakness lasted for roughly 3 hours, but it resolved completely while she was in the car on her way to the emergency department, she can move her leg normally now. Her medical history is notable for a 20-year history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Her heart rate is 80/min, the blood pressure is 148/92 mm Hg, and the respiratory rate is 14/min. Physical exam, including a thorough neurological exam, is unremarkable; strength is 5/5 throughout her bilateral upper and lower extremities. A noncontrast CT scan of her head is shown.
output: Are you currently taking any medications?

instruction: I've been having progressive chest pain, a cough that isn't bringing anything up, and difficulty breathing for the past day. Could you please tell me your age? I'm 27 years old. Could you please tell me your sex? I am a man.
input: A 27-year-old man from Southern California presents with progressive chest pain, non-productive cough, and shortness of breath for the past 24 hours. He denies any similar symptoms in the past. He denies any family history of cardiac disease, recent travel, or exposure to sick contacts. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 105/min, blood pressure is 108/78 mm Hg, and the respiratory rate is 32/min. On physical examination, patient is cachectic and ill-appearing. Bilateral pleural friction rubs are present on pulmonary auscultation. Antecubital track marks are noted bilaterally. An echocardiogram is performed and results are shown below.
output: Do you have any medical conditions or take any medications?

instruction: I've got a spreading rash that started behind my ears and now it's on my trunk and arms and legs, sore throat, red and itchy eyes, and a headache. How old are you? I am 4 years old. Do you have a fever? Yes, I have a fever. Do you have any cough or runny nose? No, I don't have a cough or runny nose.
input: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a progressive rash for 2 days. The rash started behind the ears and now involves the trunk and extremities. Over the past 4 days, he has had mild sore throat, red, itchy eyes, and headache. He was born at term and has been healthy except for recurrent episodes of tonsillitis and occasional asthma attacks. Two weeks ago, he was treated for tonsillitis that resolved with penicillin therapy. He immigrated with his family from Brazil 3 weeks ago. His immunization status is unknown. The patient appears weak and lethargic. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Examination shows postauricular and suboccipital lymphadenopathy. There is a non-confluent, pink maculopapular rash over the torso and extremities. His palms and soles show no abnormalities.
output: Do you have swollen glands in your neck or behind your ears?

instruction: My baby has been vomiting and hasn't been able to poop. How old is your baby? My baby is 10 months old. Is your baby a boy or a girl? The case vignette doesn't mention whether my baby is a boy or a girl. How long has your baby been experiencing these symptoms? He started vomiting multiple times over the past couple of hours. Is your baby's vomit green or yellow in color? The most recent vomit was green.
input: A 10-month-old infant is brought in by his parents because he is vomiting and not passing stool. His parents say he has vomited multiple times over the past couple of hours, but the most recent vomit was green. The patient has no significant past medical history. On physical examination, the patient is irritable and crying. On palpation in the periumbilical region, an abdominal mass is present. Emergency laparotomy is performed, which shows a part of the patient’s intestine folded into the section adjacent to it.
output: Does your baby have abdominal swelling or signs of abdominal pain?

instruction: I found a lump in my left breast about 6 months ago. Could you please tell me your age and sex? I'm a 24-year-old woman.
input: A 24-year-old woman with a past medical history significant only for endometriosis presents to the outpatient clinic with a 2-cm left breast mass that she first identified 6 months earlier. On review of systems, the patient states that the mass is not painful and, by her estimation, has not significantly increased in size since she first noticed it. On physical examination, there is a palpable, round, rubbery, mobile mass approximately 2 cm in diameter.
output: Has the lump changed in size or caused any pain?

instruction: I have a mass in my eye that has been there for the past month. How old are you? I am 37 years old. Could you please tell me your sex or gender? The case vignette doesn't specify my sex or gender. Are you experiencing any changes in your vision? No, I haven't mentioned any changes in my vision. Are you experiencing any pain or discomfort in your eye? No, the physical exam did not elicit any pain. Do you have any medical conditions or take any medications? I have a history of blepharitis, which was treated with eye cleansing, and squamous cell carcinoma of the skin, treated with Mohs surgery.
input: A 37-year-old machinist presents to his primary care physician with eye problems. The patient states that he has had a mass in his eye that has persisted for the past month. The patient has a past medical history of blepharitis treated with eye cleansing and squamous cell carcinoma of the skin treated with Mohs surgery. His temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 157/102 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for a firm and rubbery nodule palpable inside the patient's left eyelid. Physical exam does not elicit any pain.
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Chalazion

instruction: I'm having trouble with feeding and I keep getting yeast and other infections frequently. How old are you? I’m 4 months old.
input: A 4-month-old adopted infant is brought to the pediatrician because of feeding problems and recurrent fungal and bacterial infections. Her family has almost no background information about the infant. They report that she is a little fragile and looks different compared to other infants her age. Physical evaluation reveals a cleft lip with intact hard and soft palate and mild jaw malformation. An echocardiogram reveals an interrupted aortic arch. Further investigation reveals leukopenia and mild hypocalcemia.
output: What is your sex?

instruction: I've been experiencing shortness of breath when I do physical activities and a dry cough for about a year now.
input: A 65-year-old male engineer presents to the office with shortness of breath on exertion and a dry cough that he has had for about a year. He is a heavy smoker with a 25-pack-years history. His vitals include: heart rate 95/min, respiratory rate 26/min, and blood pressure 110/75 mm Hg. On examination, he presents with nail clubbing and bilateral and persistent crackling rales. The chest radiograph shows basal reticulonodular symmetric images, with decreased lung fields. The pulmonary function tests show the following: diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide (DLCO) is 43% and reference SaO2 is 94% and 72%, at rest and with exercise, respectively.
output: Could you please tell me your age and sex?

instruction: I have a severe headache and get sudden, severe pain over my face whenever anything touches it. Can you please tell me your age and sex? I'm a 23-year-old man. How long have you been experiencing these symptoms? I didn't mention how long I've been experiencing these symptoms. Do you have any medical conditions or take any medications? I didn't mention any medical conditions or medications. Is the facial pain on one side of your face or both? The information about whether the pain is on one side of the face or both was not provided.
input: A 23-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a severe headache. The patient states he gets sudden, severe pain over his face whenever anything touches it, including shaving or putting lotion on his skin. He describes the pain as electric and states it is only exacerbated by touch. He is currently pain free. His temperature is 98.1°F (36.7°C), blood pressure is 127/81 mmHg, pulse is 87/min, respirations are 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Neurological exam is within normal limits, except severe pain is elicited with light palpation of the patient’s face. The patient is requesting morphine for his pain.
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Trigeminal Neuralgia

instruction: I've been having burning pain in my neck and arms for a year and sometimes I feel tingling in my hands. Could you please tell me your age and sex? I am a 58-year-old man.
input: A 58-year-old man comes to the physician because of burning pain in his neck and arms for a year. He has also had paresthesias in his hands during this period. He has had increasing weakness in both hands during the past 3 months. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypercholesterolemia, and hypertension. He was involved in a motor vehicle collision 3 years ago. Current medications include metformin, sitagliptin, enalapril, atorvastatin, and aspirin. He has had 7 sexual partners in his lifetime; he uses condoms inconsistently. He is oriented to time, place, and person. Vital signs are within normal limits. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Examination of the upper extremities shows decreased muscle strength, absent reflexes, and decreased hand grip with fasciculations bilaterally. Sensation to temperature and pain is absent over the chest and bilateral upper arms. Vibration and joint position sensations are present in the upper limbs. Cranial nerve examination shows no focal findings. Examination of the lower extremities show no abnormalities.
output: Do you have any other medical conditions?

instruction: I've got some small bumps on my left thigh that don't itch, and I've been feeling really tired and generally unwell for the past few months. May I know your age? I'm 44 years old. What is your sex? I am a man. Are you currently taking any medications? No, I'm not taking any medications. Do you have any other medical conditions or a history of any illnesses? No, I have no known medical problems. Have you experienced any unexplained weight loss or night sweats? No, I haven't experienced any unexplained weight loss or night sweats. Have the bumps changed in size or appearance? They have not changed in size and they have a central indentation.
input: A 44-year-old man presents to the family medicine clinic for some small bumps on his left thigh. The lesions are non-pruritic and have been present for the last 3 weeks. He reports feeling fatigued and malaise for the past few months. The patient has no known medical problems and takes no medications. He smokes one pack of cigarettes per day and uses intravenous street drugs. His heart rate is 82/min, the respiratory rate is 14/min, the temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), and the blood pressure is 126/80 mm Hg. Auscultation of the heart is without murmurs. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Three 2-3 mm, dome-shaped, hardened papules are noted on the left thigh. Central umbilication can be observed in each papule. There is a non-tender cervical lymphadenopathy present.
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Molluscum contagiosum

instruction: I've been having a low-grade fever, an itchy rash, and my joints have been hurting everywhere for the past two days.
input: An 8-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of low-grade fever, itchy rash, and generalized joint pain. The rash initially started in the antecubital and popliteal fossae and then spread to her trunk and distal extremities. One week ago, she was diagnosed with acute sinusitis and was started on amoxicillin. She has no history of adverse drug reactions and immunizations are up-to-date. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows periorbital edema and multiple erythematous, annular plaques of variable sizes over her entire body. One of the lesions in the right popliteal fossa has an area of central clearing and the patient's mother reports that it has been present for over 24 hours. Urinalysis is normal.
output: How old are you?

instruction: I've noticed a brown rough spot on my left shin that I saw while shaving my leg.
input: A 22-year-old female presents with a brown rough spot on the left shin which she noted when shaving her leg. She thinks it may have been there for a few weeks. She denies any pain, pruritus, or spontaneous bleeding from the site. She cannot recall any trauma that may have caused the lesion.  She denies any personal or family history of skin cancer.   Physical exam reveals a thin, firm brown dome shaped papule on the left shin that invaginates upon pinching.
output: May I know your age and gender?

instruction: I have a diffuse, itchy rash over my abdomen, back, and upper legs that started about a week ago. How old are you? I am 7 years old. Are you experiencing any other symptoms besides the rash? No, I'm otherwise feeling well and I don't have any other symptoms. Has anyone else around you developed a similar rash? No, I haven't been around anyone else who is sick or has a similar rash. Have you recently started using any new soaps, lotions, or detergents? No, I haven't started using any new soaps, lotions, or detergents.
input: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his mother for complaints of a diffuse, itchy rash over his abdomen, back, and upper legs. The rash first appeared about 1 week ago. He has otherwise been well, and he has no known sick contacts. On exam he is afebrile and cooperative. His skin exam (Figure A) is notable for a single large, well-circumscribed pink plaque over his mid-abdomen, and many pink papules of varying sizes over his abdomen, back, and thighs. On follow-up a month later, the rash has largely resolved without intervention.
output: Is the itching more severe at night?

instruction: I've been having left knee pain for the past 6 weeks, and it gets really bad when I'm running up and down the stairs.
input: A 12-year-old girl presents to her primary care physician with left knee pain for the past 6 weeks. She recently joined the field hockey team at her school. The pain is the most severe when she is running up and down the stairs at the school stadium. The pain decreases when she goes home and rests after practice. She additionally admits to tripping and landing on her left knee 5 days ago. Physical exam shows a knee with a healing abrasion over the left patella. The tibial tuberosity is tender to palpation. A radiograph of the knee is presented in figure A.
output: What is your age and gender?

instruction: I've been having worsening abdominal pain for the last few hours, and I feel nauseated. Could you please tell me your age and sex? I'm a 72-year-old man. Where is the abdominal pain located? The abdominal pain is all over my belly; it doesn't seem to be in one specific spot. Have you been vomiting or had any changes in your bowel movements? No, I haven't been vomiting, and there haven't been any changes in how my bowel movements look. Do you have any medical conditions or take any medications? Yes, I have type 2 diabetes, high blood pressure, heart disease, a history of stroke and irregular heartbeat, and I've had ulcers in my stomach before. I'm taking medications for diabetes, high blood pressure, heart rate, and to protect my stomach.
input:
A 72-year-old man presents to the ED complaining of worsening abdominal pain over the last few hours. He also reports nausea, but denies fever, vomiting, or changes in the appearance of his bowel movements. His medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, coronary artery disease, stroke, atrial fibrillation, and peptic ulcer disease. Due to his recurrent bleeding peptic ulcers, he does not take warfarin. His surgical history is significant for an appendectomy as a child. His medications include metformin, lisinopril, metoprolol, and omeprazole. He has a 50-pack-year history of smoking. His temperature is 37.6 C (99.7 F), blood pressure is 146/80 mm Hg, pulse is 115/min, and respiratory rate is 20/min. On physical exam, he is in acute distress due to the pain. Pulmonary auscultation reveals scattered wheezes and decreased air entry. His heart rate is irregularly irregular, with no murmurs, rubs or gallops. Abdominal exam is significant for decreased bowel sounds and diffuse tenderness. Initial laboratory evaluation is as follows:
Na 138 mEq/L, Cl 101 mEq/L, HCO3 12 mEq/L, BUN 21 mg/dL, Cr 0.9 mg/dL, glucose 190 mg/dL, amylase 240 U/L (normal < 65 U/L).
output: Are you experiencing any chest pain or shortness of breath?

instruction: I have this single spot on my left arm that has turned brown, become hard, and it doesn't sweat or grow hair. How old are you? I am 46 years old.
input: The patient is a 46-year-old woman who presents at your primary care office for an examination with a single lesion that appears on her left arm. During the examination, it is revealed that the patient has a large sclerotic, indurated, hyperpigmented, anhidrotic, and hairless plaque on the right dorsal forearm. The patient states that these lesions had previously been slightly pink for several months before they had turned brown in color and had become “hard.” The patient has type 2 diabetes, but she has no other medical problems. In addition, she has no relevant social or family history.
output: Could you please tell me your sex?

instruction: I have a rash on my face, chest, and arms, and it gets worse when I'm in the sun, along with joint pain. Could you please tell me your age and sex? I'm a 42-year-old man. Do you have any other medical conditions? No, I don't have any prior medical history. Are you currently taking any medications? Yes, I've been taking over-the-counter pain relievers for the joint pain and creams for the rash, but they haven't helped.
input: A 42-year-old Hispanic man with no prior medical history presents with a 2-month history of a rash on his face, chest, and arms. He reports that the rash gets worse after sun exposure and he has associated joint pain. He has taken over-the-counter nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) for the joint pain and topical steroids for the rash with no symptomatic relief. Physical examination reveals erythematous patches over the malar cheeks and dorsal nose sparing the nasolabial fold and erythematous macules on the forearms and chest.
output: Could you describe how the rash looks?

instruction: I have a growing bump on the side of my neck that sometimes bleeds when I rub it, but it doesn't hurt or itch.
input: A 28-year-old healthy white woman with no significant past medical history presents with an enlarging papule on her right lateral neck. She describes a 1- to 2-mm pink papule that grew to approximately 10 mm within the past week. With minimal rubbing or trauma, the papule intermittently bleeds. It is otherwise nontender and nonpruritic. She has no history of skin cancer and is taking oral contraceptives. Physical examination shows a pink, friable papule on a stalk on the right lateral neck. There are no other similar lesions seen on examination.
output: May I know your age and gender?

instruction: I've been having diarrhea, not gaining weight well, losing hair, and a rash around my mouth, bottom, and on my hands and feet. How old are you? I am 7 months old. Is the child breastfed, formula-fed, or both? I was exclusively breastfed until 2 months ago, and then I was switched to formula.
input: A 7-month-old male who had been born prematurely presents with a 2-month history of diarrhea, failure to thrive, alopecia, and rash involving the perioral, perianal, and acral areas. He had been treated unsuccessfully for presumed atopic dermatitis with topical corticosteroids. He was exclusively breastfed until 2 months ago, when he was transitioned to formula. Examination reveals an irritable, thin infant with sharply demarcated red, inflamed, scaly plaques and erosions around his mouth, anus, eyes, hands, and feet. Diffuse hair loss is noted on the scalp, eyebrows, and eyelashes. Paronychia and nail dystrophy are noted on his upper and lower extremities.
output: Final Diagnosis: Acrodermatitis enteropathica

instruction: I have some skin changes on my neck and arms that started around puberty with yellow spots that have grown together into net-like patches. Could you please tell me your age and sex? I am a 22-year-old woman.
input: A 22-year-old woman presents for evaluation of progressive skin changes on her neck and arms beginning sometime around puberty. She tried various over-the-counter anti-itch, antiaging, and eczema creams that were ineffective. She has no personal or family history of skin conditions and is otherwise healthy. Review of systems is negative for skin laxity, joint hypermobility, or vision changes. Physical examination reveals numerous nontender, noninflammatory, yellow, 2- to 5-mm papules that coalesce into reticulated plaques on the nape of her neck and bilateral antecubital fossa. A punch biopsy demonstrates fragmentation and calcification of elastic fibers.
output: Do you have any problems with your vision?

instruction: I have multiple painful sores with pus on my private parts that I noticed 2 days ago. What is your age and gender? I'm a 21-year-old woman.
input: A 21-year-old woman comes to the physician because of multiple painful, purulent ulcers she noticed on her vulva 2 days ago. The patient has not had fever or burning with urination. She has no history of similar lesions. She had a chlamydial infection at 17 years of age that was treated with antibiotics. Her immunizations are up-to-date. She is sexually active with her boyfriend of 2 months and uses an oral contraceptive; they use condoms inconsistently. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 94/min, and blood pressure is 120/76 mm Hg. Examination shows tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. There are 4 tender, purulent 1.5-cm ulcers with a necrotic base along the labia majora.
output: Have you had any recent sexual activity?

instruction: I've got a spreading rash that started behind my ears and now it's on my trunk and arms and legs, sore throat, red and itchy eyes, and a headache. How old are you? I am 4 years old.
input: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a progressive rash for 2 days. The rash started behind the ears and now involves the trunk and extremities. Over the past 4 days, he has had mild sore throat, red, itchy eyes, and headache. He was born at term and has been healthy except for recurrent episodes of tonsillitis and occasional asthma attacks. Two weeks ago, he was treated for tonsillitis that resolved with penicillin therapy. He immigrated with his family from Brazil 3 weeks ago. His immunization status is unknown. The patient appears weak and lethargic. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Examination shows postauricular and suboccipital lymphadenopathy. There is a non-confluent, pink maculopapular rash over the torso and extremities. His palms and soles show no abnormalities.
output: Do you have a fever?

instruction: I've been experiencing on-and-off fever and a decreased appetite for the past couple of weeks, and I have painful blisters in my genital area. What is your age and sex? I am a 30-year-old woman. Have you been sexually active recently? Yes, I have been sexually active with 2 partners in the last 3 months. Are you currently taking any medications? I take oral contraceptives and a multivitamin daily. Are you experiencing any pain or burning during urination? No, I haven't mentioned any pain or burning during urination. Have you noticed any other symptoms, such as headache, muscle aches, or swollen lymph nodes? Yes, I have swollen and tender lymph nodes in my groin area.
input: A 30-year-old woman presents to her primary care provider complaining of intermittent fever and loss of appetite for the past 2 weeks. She is also concerned about painful genital lesions. Past medical history is noncontributory. She takes oral contraceptives and a multivitamin daily. She has had two male sexual partners in her lifetime and uses condoms inconsistently. She admits to being sexually active with 2 partners in the last 3 months and only using condoms on occasion. Today, her vitals are normal. On pelvic exam, there are red-rimmed, fluid-filled blisters over the labia minora (as seen in the photograph below) with swollen and tender inguinal lymph nodes.
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Genital herpes

instruction: I have nausea and a headache, and I've vomited twice in the last half hour. Can you please tell me your age and gender? I am a 27-year-old woman. Are you currently taking any medications or have any medical conditions? No, I take no medications and I have no history of serious illness. Are you experiencing fever or neck stiffness? My temperature is normal at 37°C, and you didn't mention anything about neck stiffness, so as far as you've informed me, no neck stiffness. Are you experiencing sensitivity to light or sound? You didn't describe those symptoms to me, so no, I am not experiencing sensitivity to light or sound. Can you describe the location and severity of your headache? The headache is severe, but you didn't specify its location, except for mentioning a bruise on the right side of my head. Have you recently experienced any head injury or trauma? Yes, I hit my head on the sidewalk after falling from my bicycle. Did you lose consciousness when you fell? Yes, I lost consciousness for a couple of minutes following the accident.
input: A 27-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after sustaining a fall from her bicycle 1 hour ago. The patient was on her way to work as she lost her balance, hitting her head on the sidewalk. She had an initial loss of consciousness for a couple of minutes following the accident. She currently has nausea and a headache. She has vomited twice during the last 30 minutes. She has no history of a serious illness. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. She has never used illicit drugs. She takes no medications. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 50/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. She is oriented to person, place, and time. Her lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows bradycardia but no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. The abdomen is soft and nontender. There is a bruise on the right temporal side of the head. While performing the remainder of the physical examination the patient starts having a seizure. Intravenous lorazepam is administered and she is admitted to the intensive care unit.
output: Final Diagnosis: Epidural Hematoma

instruction: I have a rash on my face and upper arms, and I also had fevers and muscle aches in my thighs a few days ago. Could you please tell me your age and sex? I'm a 7-year-old girl. Are you having trouble running or getting up from sitting? No, I don't have any trouble with that. Could you please describe how the rash looks? The rash is bright pink and red with a lacy, net-like pattern on my cheeks, but it doesn't cover the area around my mouth and the folds from my nose to the corners of my lips, and there are also some faint patches on my upper arms. Are you experiencing any joint pain or swelling? No, I'm not having any joint pain or swelling.
input: A 7-year-old female presents for evaluation of facial rash that began three days ago. The patient's mother reports four days before the rash began, the patient had some fevers and thigh muscle aches. Mother notes many other children at the school have had a similar rash. On examination, on the bilateral cheeks are bright pink red lacy reticulated erythematous patches with sparing of the perioral and mesolabial fold with similar faint patches on the bilateral upper arms. No lesions are appreciated in oral mucosa. Patient is up to date with vaccinations.
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Fifth disease (Erythema infectiosum)

instruction: I've been experiencing fever, cough, weakness, night sweats, and poor appetite for the last 6 months. How old are you? I am 68 years old.
input: A 68-year-old man presents to the physician with fever, cough, weakness, night sweats, and poor appetite for the past 6 months. Medical records suggest that he has lost 7.5 kg (16.5 lb) of weight during this period. There is no history of breathlessness, nasal discharge, nasal obstruction, palpitations, chest pain, or symptoms related to digestion. He was released from prison 9 months ago after serving a 2-year sentence. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 122/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows hepatomegaly and generalized lymphadenopathy, and auscultation of the chest reveals diffuse crackles throughout the lung fields bilaterally. On direct ophthalmoscopy, three discrete, yellow-colored, 0.5 mm to 1.0 mm lesions with indistinct borders are seen in the posterior pole. A chest X-ray is shown in the image. Tuberculin skin test with purified protein derivative is negative.
output: What is your sex?

instruction: I've been experiencing shortness of breath when I do physical activities and a dry cough for about a year now. Could you please tell me your age and sex? I'm a 65-year-old male. Do you have a history of smoking? Yes, I'm a heavy smoker with a 25-pack-years history. Do you have any existing medical conditions or take any medications? I haven't mentioned any specific existing medical conditions or medications. Have you experienced any chest pain or discomfort? No, I haven't mentioned any chest pain or discomfort.
input: A 65-year-old male engineer presents to the office with shortness of breath on exertion and a dry cough that he has had for about a year. He is a heavy smoker with a 25-pack-years history. His vitals include: heart rate 95/min, respiratory rate 26/min, and blood pressure 110/75 mm Hg. On examination, he presents with nail clubbing and bilateral and persistent crackling rales. The chest radiograph shows basal reticulonodular symmetric images, with decreased lung fields. The pulmonary function tests show the following: diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide (DLCO) is 43% and reference SaO2 is 94% and 72%, at rest and with exercise, respectively.
output: Have you noticed any swelling in your legs or ankles?

instruction: I have a rash all over my body that started on my trunk and then spread to my arms and legs, and a couple of days ago, I had a very high fever and a seizure. How old are you? I am 9 months old.
input: An 9-month-old infant is brought to the physician because of a generalized nonpruritic rash for 2 days. The rash began on her trunk and spread to her extremities. Five days ago, she was taken to the emergency department for fever of 40.5°C (104.9°F) and a 1-minute generalized tonic-clonic seizure. She was born at term and has no history of serious illness. Her immunizations are up-to-date. Current medications include acetaminophen. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F) and pulse is 120/min. Examination shows a maculopapular rash that blanches on pressure. A photograph of the rash is shown. Posterior auricular lymphadenopathy is present.
output: Did the rash start after your fever ended?

instruction: I've been feeling feverish and increasingly confused for the past day. May I know your age and sex? I am a 31-year-old man. Are you experiencing any headaches or neck stiffness? My neck feels a bit stiff, but I can still move it all the way. Do you have any medical history or take any medications? Yes, I have bipolar disorder with psychotic features and hypothyroidism, and I take lithium, haloperidol, and levothyroxine.
input: A 31-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of fever and increasing confusion for the past day. He has bipolar disorder with psychotic features and hypothyroidism. Current medications are lithium, haloperidol, and levothyroxine. He drinks one beer with dinner every night. His speech is confused and he is oriented to person only. His temperature is 40°C (104°F), pulse is 124/min, and blood pressure is 160/110 mm Hg. He appears acutely ill. Examination shows diaphoresis and muscle rigidity. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ bilaterally. There is minor rigidity of the neck with full range of motion. His lungs are clear to auscultation. The abdomen is soft and nontender. His leukocyte count is 15,100/mm3 and serum creatine kinase activity is 1100 U/L.
output: Are you experiencing any nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or tremors?

instruction: I have a mass in my eye that has been there for the past month. How old are you? I am 37 years old.
input: A 37-year-old machinist presents to his primary care physician with eye problems. The patient states that he has had a mass in his eye that has persisted for the past month. The patient has a past medical history of blepharitis treated with eye cleansing and squamous cell carcinoma of the skin treated with Mohs surgery. His temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 157/102 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for a firm and rubbery nodule palpable inside the patient's left eyelid. Physical exam does not elicit any pain.
output: Could you please tell me your sex or gender?

instruction: I've noticed a brown rough spot on my left shin that I saw while shaving my leg. May I know your age and gender? I'm a 22-year-old female. How long have you had this spot? I think it may have been there for a few weeks. Has the spot changed in size or appearance? No, it hasn't changed in size or appearance. Is the spot itchy or painful? No, it's not itchy or painful. Do you have any medical conditions or take any medications? No, I don't have any medical conditions and I'm not taking any medications.
input: A 22-year-old female presents with a brown rough spot on the left shin which she noted when shaving her leg. She thinks it may have been there for a few weeks. She denies any pain, pruritus, or spontaneous bleeding from the site. She cannot recall any trauma that may have caused the lesion.  She denies any personal or family history of skin cancer.   Physical exam reveals a thin, firm brown dome shaped papule on the left shin that invaginates upon pinching.
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Dermatofibroma

instruction: I've noticed a changing discoloration of my fingers from white to red to blue, and I've been feeling increasingly tired, weak, and I've also lost some weight.
input: A 27-year-old woman was referred to a dermatology clinic due to a changing discoloration of her fingers from white to red to blue. Although she has not had any recent changes in her daily routines, she also complains of increasing fatigue, muscle weakness, and weight loss. She has a blood pressure of 126/77 mm Hg, respiratory rate of 14/min, and heart rate of 88/min. Physical examination reveals regular heart and lung sounds. Anti-U1 RNP antibodies and increased creatinine kinase were found in her serum.
output: May I know your age and sex?

instruction: I noticed a large bump on my elbow this morning that I've never seen before. May I know your age and sex, please? I am a 55-year-old man. Do you have any medical conditions or take any medications? Yes, I have diabetes. Is the bump painful or tender? No, it's not painful or tender. Is the bump soft or hard to touch? The bump feels rubbery when you touch it. Have you experienced any recent injury or trauma to your elbow? No, I haven't had any injury, but I recently started boxing.
input: A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department with an enlarged mass on his elbow he noticed this morning. He states that he has never seen it before. The patient has a past medical history of diabetes and a 35 pack-year smoking history. He recently started boxing to get into shape. His vitals are within normal limits. Physical exam is notable for a mass seen in Figure A, which is rubbery and non-tender.
output: Is there any redness or warmth over the bump?

instruction: I have a fever and a rash that hurts when touched. How old are you? I'm 3 years old. Where is the rash located? The rash is all over my body and around my mouth. Do you have any sores or blisters inside your mouth? No, the rash doesn't affect the inside of my mouth. Is your skin peeling or forming blisters? Yes, there are blisters on my skin that pop easily.
input: A 3-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a fever and a rash. This morning the patient was irritable and had a fever which gradually worsened throughout the day. He also developed a rash prior to presentation. He was previously healthy and is not currently taking any medications. His temperature is 102.0°F (38.9°C), blood pressure is 90/50 mmHg, pulse is 160/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for a scarlatiniform rash with flaccid blisters that rupture easily, covering more than 60% of the patient’s body surface. The lesions surround the mouth but do not affect the mucosa, and palpation of the rash is painful.
output: Are you taking any medications currently?

instruction: I've been having pain in my shoulder for about 4 weeks which gets worse when I reach overhead. May I know your age and gender? I'm a 65-year-old woman.
input: A 65-year-old woman presents to her primary care provider for shoulder pain. She reports that she initially thought the pain was due to "sleeping funny" on the arm, but that the pain has now lasted for 4 weeks. She denies trauma to the joint and says that the pain is worse when reaching overhead to retrieve things from her kitchen cabinets. On physical exam, the patient's shoulders are symmetric, and the right lateral shoulder is tender to palpation. The shoulder has full passive and active range of motion, although pain is reproduced on active abduction of the right arm above 90 degrees. Pain is also reproduced on passively internally rotating and then lifting the shoulder. The patient is able to resist elbow flexion without pain, and she otherwise has 5/5 strength.
output: Do you have any other medical conditions or take any medications?

instruction: I've been having a sudden bout of really itchy hives and blisters on my belly and trunk for the past three days. Could you please tell me your age and sex? I'm a 29-year-old woman.
